intro: Mentha arvensis var. scordiastrum, commonly known as the garlic mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its aromatic, slightly pungent leaves that emit a strong garlic-like scent when crushed. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are covered in fine hairs. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pale blue or purple and appear in whorled clusters. This variety is often found in moist, shady areas such as woodlands and along stream banks.
